newsitem.title: UK: FOCUS - US cold snap boosts grains, oil easier.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - US cold snap boosts grains, oil easier.

text.p: US grain prices rose briskly on Thursday on forecasts for bitter cold weather in the US Plains and concerns of "winter kill" for the crops.
Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) wheat futures were up seven to five cents per bushel in early trade with nearby May rising above $3.90.
CBOT soybean and corn futures opened higher in fast dealings, boosted by USDA weekly export sales that were well above trade expectations, trading floor sources said.

Wheat was further supported by forecasts for up to 10 inches of snow in key spring wheat planting areas. Farmers must wait for a massive snowpack to melt and soil to dry enough before they begin seeding spring wheat, traders said.
Elsewhere in commodity markets palladium fell on word that delayed Russian exports to Japan may resume in May and crude oil was under pressure after a late Wednesday sell-off.
The palladium price had climbed to a 21-month high in London early on Thursday as worries over supply gripped the market.
The concern arose from an administrative snarl-up in Russia, the biggest seller, which has stopped exports since last November. The price has increased by 40 percent since then.
But selling began on a statement from a senior Russian Ministry of Finance official that shipments to Japan, the world's leading importer, could begin next month.
Palladium fixed at $155.50 per ounce, down from $160.25.
The rare white metal is used in electronic components and is a key element in the catalytic converters which neutralise noxious gases in car exhausts.
Gold was fixed at $347.60 against $348.05 earlier.

Crude oil was under pressure in a market that began to take a less rosy view of upcoming US gasoline demand. North Sea Brent Blend crude futures, a world benchmark, for May were trading around $17.70 per barrel late in London's day, down almost 50 cents from Wednesday afternoon.
London cocoa futures rose on buying by the trade and a cessation of the recent wave of selling by speculative funds.
